title: Groff (software)
text:
Groff ( ) (also called GNU troff) is a typesetting system that creates formatted output when given plain text mixed with formatting commands. It is the <a href="GNU">GNU</a> replacement for the <a href="troff">troff</a> and <a href="nroff">nroff</a> <a href="text%20formatter">text formatter</a>s. 
Groff contains a large number of helper programs, <a href="preprocessor">preprocessor</a>s, and postprocessors including <a href="eqn%20%28software%29">eqn</a>, <a href="tbl">tbl</a>, <a href="pic%20%28troff%29">pic</a> and <a href="soelim">soelim</a>. There are also several macro packages included that duplicate, expand on the capabilities of, or outright replace the standard troff macro packages.
Groff development of new features is active, and is an important part of free, open source, and <a href="UNIX">UNIX</a> derived operating systems such as <a href="Linux">Linux</a> and <a href="Berkeley%20Software%20Distribution">BSD</a> 4.4 derivatives — notably because troff macros are used to create <a href="man%20pages">man pages</a>, the standard form of documentation on Unix and Unix-like systems.
<a href="OpenBSD">OpenBSD</a> has replaced groff with <a href="mandoc">mandoc</a> in the base install, since their 4.9 release.
History.
groff is an original implementation written primarily in <a href="C%2B%2B">C++</a> by <a href="James%20Clark%20%28programmer%29">James Clark</a> and is modeled after <a href="ditroff">ditroff</a>, including many extensions. The first version, 0.3.1, was released June 1990. The first stable version, 1.04, was announced in November 1991. groff was developed as <a href="free%20software">free software</a> to provide an easily obtained replacement for the standard AT&T troff/nroff package, which at the time was proprietary, and was not always available even on branded <a href="UNIX">UNIX</a> systems. In 1999, Werner Lemberg and Ted Harding took over maintenance of groff. The current version of groff is 1.22.4, released on .
